titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to The Jester Lounge collection, 1963, 2016 MS 677
titlestmt.author: Norie Guthrie

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Request access to this digital material (stored on Fondren Library's nearline / non-public server) by contacting Woodson Research Center staff at woodson@rice.edu. The video oral history is online at scholarship.rice.edu.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-06-16 15:54:39 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.abstract: This collection includes audio and an oral history.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Jester Lounge opened in Houston on 2509 Midlane, which is now roughly 4608 Westheimer in 1961. Owned by Mac Webster, the folk club featured national touring acts, as well as a stable of local musicians, referred to as the the Jester players. They included, Lightnin' Hopkins, Guy Clark, K.T. Oslin, Frank Davis, Ken and Judy, Vivian and Scott Holtzman, and Sarah Wiggins. As the great folk scare of the early 1960s gave way to The Beatles, The Jester Lounge closed its doors in 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes audio from The Jester Lounge players and an oral history with Judy Clements of the duo Ken and Judy.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open to research. Request access to this digital material (stored on Fondren Library's nearline / non-public server) by contacting Woodson Research Center staff at woodson@rice.edu. The video oral history is online at scholarship.rice.edu.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish audio must be obtained from the content providers or their heirs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Christopher Clements and Judy Clements in 2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Jester Lounge collection, 1960s, 2016, MS 677, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

did.unittitle: Hoot 'n Holler telecast and Happy Holler telecast

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Recording of the Hoot n' Holler telecast from Thanksgiving 1963. Tracks include: Side 1: "If I Had a Hammer" - Ken and Judy; "Ribbon Bow" - Sarah Wiggins; "Sylvie" - Frank Davis; "Sylvie" - Scott Holtzman; "500 Miles" - Marijane Vandivier; "Houndog" - Rumrunners; "Wagoner's Lad" - Scott Holtzman and Kay Oslin; "Gimme Pain" - Group; "Michael" - All; "Kumbaya" - All; "Live a Humble" - Ken and Judy; "Go Tell It" - Ken and Judy; "Chickaly Leo" - Sharon; "Rattlesnake Mountain" - Frank Davis and Kay Oslin; "12 Gates" - Frank Davis and Kay Oslin; "Squirrel" - Sarah Wiggins; "Hi Lili" - Scott Holtzman and Kay Oslin; Side 2: "JFK" - Vivian Holtzman; "Barbry Allen" - Kay Oslin; "Wagoner's Lad" - Kay Oslin; "Rising Sun" - Kay Oslin; "Fen John" - Sharon; "Dona Dona" - Sharon; "Buckeye Jim" - Sharon; "Cotton Eye Joe" - Sarah Wiggins; "Johnny's Gone" - Sarah Wiggins; "Ain't No More Cane on This Brazos" - Sarah Wiggins; "Blues Chase up a Rabbit" - Carl S.; "Tarrytown" - Sarah Wiggins; "Moonshiner" - Sarah Wiggins; "Hoe Corn" - Frank Davis; "Trouble for" - Frank Davis; "Babe" - Scott Holtzman; "Jamie" - Vivian Holtzman; "This Ain't the Life" - Scott Holtzman; "Cavern" - Scott Holtzman. Introduction voices include Marietta Marich.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Tracks include: A1 - "Santy Anno" - Ken and Judy; A2 - "Railroad Wife" - Vivian Holtzman; A3 - "Copper Kettle" - Scott Holtzman; A4 - "Trouble In Mind" - Lightnin' Hopkins; A5 - "Brave Young Sailor" - Kay Oslin; A6 - "The River Song" - Arthur Hodges; A7 - "East Virginia" - Frank Davis; B1 - "Cotton Mill Girls" - Guy Clark; B2 - "Why May Not I Love Johnny" - Sarah Wiggins; B3 - "Polushka Polya" - Jim Gun; B4 - "Pretty Saro" - Jenny Bell Dean; B5 - "I Am a Pilgrim" - Alex Martin; B6 - "My Girl" - Frank Davis and Kay Oslin; B7 - "Black Mountain Blues" - Arthur Hodges; B8 - "Waving From the Hill" - Jenny Bell and the Gradeux Sisters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. The majority of these tracks are recorded in a studio and includes outtakes. Tracks include: Side 1: Lightnin' Hopkins - Unknown song about rain; Lightnin' Hopkins - "Trouble in Mind"; Lightnin' Hopkins - Unknown song; Lightnin' Hopkins - "Trouble in Mind"; Lightnin' Hopkins - "Baby, Don't You Hear Me Calling You"; Lightnin' Hopkins - "You Know, That's My Baby"; Lightnin' Hopkins - "Take Me Back"; The Frank Davis Foundation - "Sandpiper" (written by Glen Holtzman); The Frank Davis Foundation - "Sandpiper"; Frank Davis - "What Does It Mean" [?]; Frank Davis - "Present" [?]; Frank Davis - Unknown song; Frank Davis - Unfinished outtake; Frank Davis - "Black, Brown and White"; Frank Davis - "Early Child" outtake; Frank Davis - "Howling" [?]; Frank Davis - "Mockingbird" [?] - outtakes; Frank Davis - "Looking Back In Time"; Side 2: Frank Davis - "When I See My Brother" [?]; Frank Davis - "Mississippi River" [?]; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "My Home's Across the Smoky Mountains" live; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Sand Mountain Blues" live; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Every Night When the Sun Goes In" live; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Where Did You Sleep Last Night" live; Kay Oslin - "God Bless the Child" live; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Brazos River" live; Vanity Fair - "Over There" [?]; Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Present" in studio; outtake, altered voices - "Right String But the Wrong Yo-Yo"; altered voices - "Peter Pan" in studio; outtakes; altered voices - "[?] Sunshine" in studio; altered voices - "Sweet Thang" in studio; Scott Holtzman and Kay Oslin - "You've Lost That Loving Feeling" in studio; Kay Oslin - "Cornell Crawford" in studio; [singer ?] - "Want to Sing My Song" [?] in studio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are digitized master copy WAVs and access copy MP3s. Tracks include: Side 1: Frank Davis and Kay Oslin - "Rattlesnake Mountain"; "They Gotta Quit Kicking My Dog Around" - Rum Runners; "Blues Chase up a Rabbit" - Carl S.--Check if Same; "Babe, I'm Gonna Leave You" - Scott Holtzman; "The Boy Who Wouldn't Hoe Corn" - Frank Davis; "Wagoner's Lad" - Kay Oslin and Scott Holtzman; "Wagoner's Lad" - unknown; "Banks of the Ohio" - unknown; "Down in the Willow Garden" aka "Rose Connelly" - unknown; "Early Morning Rain" - unknown; "The Pride of Petravore" - unknown; "Calton Weaver" - unknown; "Wild Mountain Thyme" - unknown; "Clear the Track" - unknown; "Hey Nelly Nelly" - unknown; Side 2: Hoot n' Holler telecast introduction; "If I Had a Hammer" - Ken and Judy; "Humble Yourself, The Bell Done Ring" - Ken and Judy; "Go Tell It on the Mountain" - Ken and Judy; "Santy Ano" - unknown; "Railroad Life" - unknown; "Copper Kettle" - unknown; "Trouble in Mind" - Lightnin' Hopkins; "As I Roved Out (Tarry Trousers)" - Kay Oslin; "The Brazos River" - unknown; "East Virginia" - Frank Davis; "Hard Times Cotton Mill Girls" - Guy Clark [?]; "Oh Dear! What Can the Matter Be?" aka "Johnny's So Long at the Fair" - unknown; "Polyushko-polye" - unknown; "Bird" song - unknown; "I'm a Pilgrim and a Stranger" - unknown; "Where Did You Sleep Last Night" - Frank Davis and Kay Oslin; "Black Mountain Blues" - unknown. Introduction voices include Marietta Marich and The Rum Runners.
